text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
This transmits revised IRM 7.20.4, Exempt Organizations Determination Letter Program, Automatic Revocation and Other Special Issues.
MATERIAL CHANGES
Incorporated procedures in Interim Guidance Memorandum TEGE-07-0716-0017, Interim Guidance for Processing Form 8976, Notiﬁcation of Intent to Operate Under Section 501(c)(4).

EFFECT ON OTHER DOCUMENTS

This IRM incorporates, supersedes and archives: Interim Guidance Memorandum TEGE-07-0716-0017, Interim Guidance for Processing Form 8976, Notiﬁcation Intent to Operate Under Section 501(c)(4). Interim Guidance Memorandum TEGE-07-0118-0002, Processing EO Determinations Correspondence with nical Issues. ) Audience: The procedures in this manual apply to all Exempt (EO) employees processing determination requests and Forms
) Policy Owner: Director, Exempt Organizations (
) Program Owner: Exempt Organizations (
) EO includes two primary operational areas: Rulings and Agreements and aminations. (
) EO Rulings and Agreements issues determination letters on exempt status, private foundation classiﬁcation, and other determinations related to exempt organizations. (
) Generally, organizations submit applications for tax-exempt status and miscellaneous determinations (Form
, Form
, Form
-A, Form
, Form
, and other letter applications) to the Cincinnati Processing Center (CSPC). (

) CSPC processes the user fee payment in the Letter Information Network User Fee System (LINUS) and scans the application/request into the Tax Exempt Determination System (TEDS). TEDS transmits the information to Employee Plans/Exempt Organizations Determination System (EDS). Note: EDS is the system of record for EO Determinations cases.
Revocation and Other Special Determination 7.20.4
Purpose: This manual describes procedures for special issues Exempt Orga- nizations Determinations (EOD) employees encounter when processing determination letter requests and Form
, Notice of Intent to Operate Under Section

), which is not a determination letter requests. Special issues are issues or processes that may not apply to every case. They require procedures unique to that issue or process. Topics in this manual include:

Audience: The procedures in this manual apply to all Exempt Organizations (EO) employees processing determination requests and Forms 8976.

CSPC processes the user fee payment in the Letter Information Network and User Fee System (LINUS) and scans the application/request into the Tax Exempt Determination System (TEDS). TEDS transmits the information to the Employee Plans/Exempt Organizations Determination System (EDS).
Note: EDS is the system of record for EO Determinations cases.
CSPC sends open hard copy case ﬁles to an IRS facility in Florence, KY.

) The Pension Protection Act of

introduced two new ﬁling provisions for tax-exempt organizations. It: • Introduced an annual notice ﬁling requirement for small tax-exempt ganizations previously not required to ﬁle annual returns, the Form
-N (e-Postcard) (see IRC

(i)). • Includes a provision that automatically revokes an organization’s exempt status when it fails to ﬁle a required annual return or notice three consecutive years effective for taxable years beginning after (see IRC
) An organization that is required to ﬁle a Form

-series annual return or notice and fails to do so for three consecutive years has its tax-exempt automatically revoked whether or not it was previously recognized as tax exempt. The IRS mails Notice CP
A, Revocation Notice for Failure to An Annual Information Return for
Years, to an automatically revoked zation’s last known address to notify it of its loss of tax-exempt status.

An organization that is required to ﬁle a Form

Reminder: Some organizations are excepted from ﬁling a Form 990-series return or notice. See IRC 6033, Treas. Reg. 1.6033-2(g), Treas. Reg. 1.6033- 2(h), and Treas. Reg. 1.6033-6, Rev. Proc. 83-23 supplemented by Rev. Proc. 95-48, and Rev. Proc. 96-10. However, an organization that
4 7.20 Exempt Organizations Determination Letter Program

claims exception from ﬁling but isn’t on record with the IRS as having established this exception (such as via a determination letter or otherwise) may have its tax-exempt status automatically revoked.
Reminder: Submission of Form
does not satisfy Form
-series ﬁling re- quirements. (
) An organization’s automatic revocation date is the due date of the third con- secutive return that isn’t ﬁled (
th day of the ﬁfth month after the end of the third ﬁscal year). The earliest possible automatic revocation date is May

) The IRS maintains a list of automatically revoked organizations on its Tax Exempt Organization Search, https://apps.irs.gov/app/eos/. Tax Exempt Organization Search lists the automatic revocation date, the date of posting Tax Exempt Organization Search, and the date of any reinstatement for each automatically revoked organization. (
) Automatically revoked organizations are updated to Status
on IDRS. (

) An automatically revoked organization may be subject to federal income tax of its revocation date. In addition, donations to organizations previously to receive tax-deductible contributions are no longer tax-deductible to donors as of the date the IRS posted its name on the Auto-Revocation list on Tax Exempt Organization Search. Note: Taxpayers may make tax-deductible contributions to an eligible whose tax-exempt status is subsequently reinstated as of the effective of reinstatement. (
) Organizations that had their tax-exempt status automatically revoked can request to have their tax-exempt status reinstated using procedures in Rev. Proc.
To request reinstatement of tax-exempt status, an must submit: • The appropriate application form or letter (for example, Form
- series, Form
-series, etc.) • All required supplemental information • The appropriate user fee (

) Conduct or obtain IDRS research on all cases to determine whether an nization is currently automatically revoked, records need to be updated to reﬂect automatic revocation, or needs actions taken to prevent an erroneous automatic revocation. Research IDRS command code BMFOLO (or INOLES) as well as BMFOLI and BMFOLT (as necessary). Note: Use BMFOLT to conﬁrm if a return was ﬁled timely (including ﬁled exten- sions). It may not be needed for every organization. (
) Import the IDRS research into the non-disclosable section of the TEDS case ﬁle. (
) Review IDRS research and information in the case ﬁle to determine if the nization is correctly in Status
or should be updated to Status

) Process the organization’s application as a “no gap” reinstatement if it: a. Submits the appropriate application before the due date of its third required return (based on its formation date); b. Isn’t approved before the due date of the third return (based on its formation date); and c. Has not ﬁled appropriate returns to prevent automatic revocation. ) If a subordinate’s tax-exempt status is revoked for failure to ﬁle for three the subordinate must apply for individual exemption in order for it to have its tax-exempt status reinstated. (

) A subordinate can’t have its tax-exempt status reinstated through the group ruling holder (parent organization) adding it back onto the group exemption roster. The IRS won’t add currently revoked subordinates to a GEN. (

7.20 Exempt Organizations Determination Letter Program

Exception: If you determine that the Status 27 subordinate itself should be auto- matically revoked, submit the request to update the organization to Status 97 and process using the standard automatic revocation proce- dures.
A tax
exempt organization that changes its form or place of organization (for example, a trust incorporates) may need to submit a new application for exemption.
Generally, if a

(c) exempt domestic business entity (classiﬁed as a corpo- ration) restructures (for example, unincorporated association to corporation or reincorporation in a different state), the surviving organization isn’t required to ﬁle a new exemption application if the surviving organization is a domestic business entity (classiﬁed as a corporation) and is carrying out the same purposes as the exempt organization that restructured. See Rev. Proc.
and Rev. Proc.
for speciﬁc new application requirements.

ration) restructures (for example, unincorporated association to or reincorporation in a different state), the surviving organization isn’t required to ﬁle a new exemption application if the surviving organization domestic business entity (classiﬁed as a corporation) and is carrying out same purposes as the exempt organization that restructured. See Rev.
and Rev. Proc.

for speciﬁc new application requirements. a. The effective date of exemption for the new organization is generally formation date of the new organization if it timely ﬁled the application otherwise meets requirements for exemption. b. If a new organization is formed (for example, a trust incorporates), the new organization is required to obtain a new EIN. An organization is generally not required to obtain a new EIN for any other changes in or place of organization (for example, an association incorporates or a corporation reincorporates in a different state). ) An organization could be automatically revoked in error or prematurely for a number of reasons, including: • The organization’s EIN establishment date on IDRS is before the tax year of the organization’s date of formation. • The organization had a determination letter indicating it wasn’t to ﬁle annual returns but IDRS was incorrectly coded. • A prior application for exemption was incorrectly processed. Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.
D

The effective date of exemption for the new organization is generally the formation date of the new organization if it timely ﬁled the application and otherwise meets requirements for exemption. If a new organization is formed (for example, a trust incorporates), the new organization is required to obtain a new EIN. An organization is generally not required to obtain a new EIN for any other changes in form or place of organization (for example, an association incorporates or a corporation reincorporates in a different state). The Protecting Americans from Tax Hikes (PATH) Act of 2015 created IRC 506 requiring an organization described in IRC 501(c)(4) to notify the no later than 60 days after the organization is organized that it is operating as a 501(c)(4) organization.
